attributes.title: Comparison of RST and ODNI methods for evaluating quality of reasoning

q1.value: Comparison of RST and ODNI methods for evaluating quality of reasoning

q2.value: Ashley Barnett, Tamar Primoratz, Luke Thorburn, Simon Dennis, Tim van Gelder

q3.value:
The industry standard method for evaluating quality of reasoning (QoR) in intelligence-styled products is the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence's (ODNI) Rating Scale for Evaluating Analytic Tradecraft Standards. Our research group has developed an alternative method for evaluating quality of reasoning, the Reasoning Stress Test (RST), which focuses on detecting the presence of particular types of reasoning flaws.

The main aim of this study is to compare the ability of participants trained in each method to discriminate between well and poorly reasoned intelligence-style products. A product is said to be 'well reasoned' if its arguments establishes its conclusion. Otherwise, it is said to be 'poorly reasoned'. As the RST has been designed to aid identification of flaws that would undermine an argument's conclusion, we believe that participants trained in the RST may be better able to discriminate between well and poorly reasoned products than those trained using the ODNI method. Testing this hypothesis is the main aim of this study, and the methodology we will use to answer it is outlined in this pre-registration.

We have a number of secondary aims, which will be the subject of exploratory analysis. Some of these are outlined under the question on exploratory analyses in the Analysis Plan section of this pre-registration.

q4.value: Participants who have received training in and are applying the RST method will be better able to discriminate between well and poorly reasoned intelligence-style products than those trained in and applying the ODNI method, where ability to discriminate is measured by the d' measure of sensitivity used in Signal Detection Theory. The difference in d' for the two groups will be estimated (rather than calculated directly) using a binomial GLM with probit link, as outlined in our analysis plan.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Primarily, this is a two-group, between subject, design.

Once a subject has consented to participate, they will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. The sequence of tasks the two groups will complete are summarised below.

GROUP 1 (RST then ODNI)

1. RST training module
2. Demographic survey
3. Application of RST method to sample intelligence products
4. ODNI training module
5. Application of ODNI method to sample intelligence products 

GROUP 2 (ODNI then RST)

1. ODNI training module
2. Demographic survey
3. Application of ODNI method to sample intelligence products
4. RST training module
5. Application of RST method to sample intelligence products

At stages 3 and 5 in each group, subjects will be guided through a series of 18 sample intelligence products, and asked to use the method in which they have just been trained to evaluate the QoR in each product. Of the 18 products, 7 are well-reasoned, and 11 are poorly-reasoned.

To isolate the effects of training in each method, only evaluations from stage 3 will be used to answer the primary research question. Further, due to the length of stages 1 and 3, it is not expected that many participants will complete stages 4 and 5. If there is a meaningful amount of data collected in stages 4 and 5, it might be used for exploratory analysis.

To maximise learning outcomes for subjects, they will be provided with feedback immediately after evaluating each product. The feedback will indicate whether or not their evaluation of the product was correct, along with details and justifications for the correct evaluation of the product. This will likely cause learning effects to be present. To counterbalance learning effects, the order in which the products are presented to subjects will be randomised.

A secondary aim of the study is to collect preliminary data on the robustness of each method to variations in communication style. To this end, 4 of the products have two variants. Two well-reasoned products have an additional 'poorly written' version that contains spelling and grammatical errors, verbosity and repetition; and two poorly-reasoned products have an additional, 'impressively written' version that contains jargon, obfuscation, and “officialese”. For these 4 products, each subject will only see one version, chosen at random.

As the we want to retain the ability to use the test products used for this study in future, as well to to potentially sell access to the training package, we are not attaching them to this registration. If you would like to see the training modules and test products used for this study, please contact Ashley Barnett at Barnett.a@unimelb.edu.au.

q9.value:
Each participant will be assigned uniformly at random to either Group 1 or Group 2. The size of these groups is not fixed in advance. The randomisation occurs when the participant loads the landing page on our research group's website, which (once they consent to participate) takes them to the relevant training module in Thinkific. Which training module they are taken two depends on whether a single random integer generated using the `window.crypto.getRandomValues` function in JavaScript is odd or even.

In stages 3 and 5, the order products are presented in, and which communication version of a product (if there are more than one) the participants sees, is also randomised. This randomisation is performed using inbuilt functionality in the Qualtrics platform.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value:
At the time of pre-registration, some data that will be used in the study has been collected, but no human has observed it.

The training and study platform has been open to the public since January 30, 2020. The period between January 30 and February 13, 2020, was treated as a pilot, with the small amount of data collected used to gauge the level of engagement of participants with the training materials and test products. We also used this period to improve the presentation of the training materials so that it is more clearly structured and engaging, and to troubleshoot technical issues with the course platform. No data from this pilot period will be used in the study.

On February 13, 2020, we finalised our amendments to the training materials and test products, and opened collection of data for the study proper. Since then, a small number of participants (fewer than 10) have already completed the training and test materials, but no human has seen this data.

question.value:
RECRUITMENT AND POPULATION

Participation in the study will be voluntary and unpaid. Participants will be invited to participate through multiple channels, including:

- from government departments and intelligence organisations in Five Eyes countries, via relationships our research group has with those organisations;
- from a pool of subjects who have been involved in previous studies undertaken by our research group, re-invited via email;
- from the general public, invited via Facebook ads and a public invitation on the Hunt Lab website.

To encourage participation, the study will be presented as a valuable opportunity for professional learning. For many participants, the training they received in evaluating quality of reasoning will be applicable beyond the context of the study.

EILIGIBILITY

Participants cannot be members of our (extended) research group or have participated in any pilot studies in which they will have already seen versions of the products. Additional criteria for data exclusion are outlined under the relevant question in the Analysis plan section. Otherwise, there are no criteria which make subjects ineligible to participate. 

Participants will be separately asked whether they have previously encountered either of the two evaluation methods, and their response to these questions will be included as a variable in our model. (While the RST is a new, unpublished method, some participants may have encountered an earlier version of it in pilot studies we have run.)

The substantial length of the training modules is also expected to prompt participants to ‘self-filter’ and abandon the training if they are either (a) not sufficiently committed/engaged or (b) already familiar with the material, both of which are undesirable qualities for the purposes of the study, but difficult to test for in advance of delivering the training. For these participants, no evaluations for intelligence products will be collected, because they will not make it past the training.

STUDY TIMELINE

The training and evaluation modules are available online and designed to operate indefinitely. They were opened to the public on 13 February, 2020.

Details of the stopping rule for the purposes of this study are included below.

q13.value:
The number of participants in the study is not fixed in advance. Each participant will evaluate at most 18 products, but fewer if they do not complete all evaluations.

For the confirmatory part of the study, we will stop collecting data on June 1, 2020. We aim to collect a minimum of 7200 product evaluations by that date. If every participant completes all 18 product evaluations, this is equivalent to 400 participants. We will stop collecting data for the confirmatory part of the study on this date, regardless of whether our target is met.

q14.value:
The stopping date of June 1, 2020 has been set for financial reasons.

The target sample size of 7200 product evaluations is the result of power analysis using simulated data. These suggest that if the true (hit,false alarm) rates are (60%,40%) for the ODNI, and (70%,40%) for the RST, then the difference in d' between the two methods will be detected using a 0.05 p-value threshold with probability of 0.92, assuming 400 participants complete all 18 product evaluations.

The code used to perform this power analysis is included in the 'Registration: Analysis Code.R' file, attached to this pre-registration.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data (for the purposes of confirmatory analyses) on June 1, 2020. Until that date, we will recruit participants via the previously described channels, with the aim of collected a minimum of 7200 product evaluations.

question.value: A data dictionary is attached for all measured variables that will be used in confirmatory analyses.
No indices such as including hit or false alarm rates, will be computed prior to modelling (see the analysis plan section). Each product evaluation will be treated as a distinct observation.

q20.value: Data will be recoded so that it is in the same format as the simulated data in the previously-attached R script, as described in the previously attached Data Dictionary file. This will entail reconciling datasets from the two platforms (Thinkific and Qualtrics) being used to deliver the different stages of training and product evaluation, and recoding categorical variables for the  purposes of modelling. The coding scheme used for modelling is detailed in the Data Dictionary.

q21.value: We will use a single two-tailed, Wald-type test of whether the coefficient for the interaction between usedRST and isPoor variables in non-zero, with a p-value threshold of 0.05.

q22.value:
Data will be excluded if:

- the participant is a member of our (extended) research group, or

- the participant participated in pilot studies that used versions of the same test products used in this study, or

- the participant indicates that they are under 18 years of age, or

- the participant does not follow the instruction to use the same email address for both the training in Thinkific and the product evaluations in Qualtrics, because in this case we will be unable to determine which evaluation method the participant received training in, or

- the participant registers for the study multiple times (and hence may be allocated to both groups).

Otherwise, all product evaluations collected according to the sampling plan will be included in the analysis. We have decided to model some potential confounders, such as whether the participant has encountered the RST or ODNI method (but not the test products) before, rather than exclude participants on those grounds.

q23.value:
Subjects will not be able to proceed to the product evaluation stage without first inputting the demographic covariates used in the model, so we do not anticipate any missing covariates. The categorical levels of the age and education level covariates include options for those who prefer not to answer, and if there are any respondents who select those options, those options will included in the model.

If a participant does not complete all 18 product evaluations, we will still include the evaluations which they did complete.

We will not include partially-completed or not-attempted product evaluations.

q24.value:
A non-exhaustive list of exploratory research questions we intend to investigate is included below.

- How robust are the ODNI and RST methods for evaluating QoR to the presence of communication style confounds?

- Do the methods help participants identify the actual reasoning problems present in test products?

- Are participants trained using the RST better able to detect certain types of reasoning flaws?

- How do the inter-rater reliabilities of the ODNI and RST methods compare, and how does this measure of reliability fit within the context the methods' possibly differing abilities to discriminate between well and poorly reasoned test products?

attributes.title: The Role of Emotion in Decision Making Process of Chinese-English Bilinguals
attributes.description: This project aims to examine and compare the effect of emotion on linguistic decision-making in both native and second language of Chinese-English bilinguals.

q1.value: The Role of Emotion in Decision Making Process of Chinese-English Bilinguals

q3.value: Previous research has shown that negative stimuli have preferential access to perceptual processing, and this high sensitivity towards negative stimuli has significant adaptive value (Nasrallah, Carmel, & Lavie, 2009). It has also been suggested that thinking in a foreign language may reduce biases in decision-making as foreign languages may create a greater emotional distance than native language (Keysar, Hayakawa, & An, 2012). This foreign language effect has also been identified in moral dilemmas and economic scenarios (Pavlenko, 2017). Therefore, this project aims to examine and compare the impact of emotion on linguistic decision-making in both native and second language of Chinese-English bilinguals.

q4.value:
1. The contingency ratings will be highest for negative words and lowest for neutral words. An interaction effect between the language and valence of emotional words is expected with the self-reported contingency rate higher in native language than the second language.  
2. There will be a negative relationship between the reaction time and the arousal level of emotional words while a positive correlation between the accuracy rate and arousal level of words will be expected. A faster reaction and higher accuracy will be expected when the emotional words are presented in the native language.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 (native and second languages) x 3 (Positive, Neutral, Negative valence of emotional words) within-subject design

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where participants will be randomly assigned to either "Chinese-first" or "English-first" block sequence for counterbalance.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: One-hundred students who identified themselves as Chinese-English bilinguals from the University of Hong Kong would be recruited via email and poster. There will be no monetary compensation for participation.

q13.value: Aiming at an effect size of .5, a minimum number of 14 participants is needed. We will attempt to recruit 100 participants.

q14.value:
Power Analysis 

F tests - ANOVA: Repeated measures, within factors
Analysis:	A priori: Compute required sample size 
Input:	Effect size f	=	0.5
		α err prob	=	0.05
		Power (1-β err prob)	=	0.95
		Number of groups	=	2
		Number of measurements	 =	3
		Corr among rep measures 	=	0.5
		Nonsphericity correction ε	=	1
Output:	Noncentrality parameter λ	=	21.0000000
		Critical F	=	3.4028261
		Numerator df	=	2.0000000
		Denominator df	=	24.0000000
		Total sample size 	=	14
		Actual power	=	0.9773161

question.value:
IV 1: Language of words (Chinese, English)
IV 2: Valence of words (Positive, Neutral, Negative)

For Study 1: Contingency ratings between emotional words and geometric shapes
For Study 2: Reaction time and accuracy rate of response to recognition tasks
I will use a 2 x 3 repeated measure ANOVA to analyze the results.

q21.value: The standard p < .05 criteria for determining the significance of ANOVA results will be used in this project.

q22.value: Outliers will be excluded from the dataset.

q23.value: Missing data will not be included in the analysis.

q1.value: An Exploratory Analysis on Goal Representation

q3.value:
The present study is an exploratory project aiming at investigating how people frame and think about their daily goals. Even though there has been a large amount of literature related to the construct of goal, there's little consensus on how we should quantify and measure this multi-dimensional construct. This current project will lay the groundwork for future studies on goal measurement and the dynamic system among multiple goals. 

Specific research questions are 1) Can we reduce represent goals with a limited number of factors? 2) To what extent is each factor visible to other people (self-other rating consistency)? 3) How does the current goal pursuing status affect goal representation on each of the factors 4) How similar are the goals listed by a given participant 5) What are the individual differences that affect goal representation on each factor and the similarity among goals.

q4.value: This project is exploratory, and therefore we have no specific hypotheses about the relationship between our main variables.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is an online within-subject study. First, participants list all their goals (no more than 5 goals). Then, they rate each of their goals on 35 variables, whose orders are randomized. Last, they complete several measures on individual differences. The variables and individual difference measures are specified under the variable session. 

We also recruit 2 undergraduate students from the University of Oregon as raters, who rate every goal on all 30 variables related to goal representation. The raters are blind to the subjects. The only information they know about the participants is that they are average U of O undergraduate students.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via the Human Subject Pool at the University of Oregon, and therefore, participants will be undergraduate students at U of O. They will be compensated with 1 research credit. The inclusion criteria are 1) be at least 18 years old 2) English native speakers 3) currently are not diagnosed with depression

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300, and we will attempt to recruit up to 335, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: This sample size is estimated based on feasibility and time constraint.

question.value:
We collect variables related to the following aspects: 
1)	Goals: The number of participants’ current goals; A list of participants’ current goals (no more than 5)
2)	Goal representation: 30 variables about how participants’ perceive each of their goals
3)	Current goal pursuing process: 5 variables about the current status of their goal pursuing processes.
4)	Demographic background: 10 variables
5)	Individual differences: 9 standardize inventories. 

All variables are specified in the attachment.
Because this is an exploratory study, we don’t have any specific statistical models for our main research questions. Our exploratory analysis plan is specified in the exploratory analysis session.

q20.value:
Ratings on the 30  variables related to goal representation will be transformed into factor scores based on the results from the exploratory factor analysis. Ratings will be transformed using regression-based weights (set method="Thurstone" for the function “factor.scores” from the "psych" library). 

Ratings on standardized individual difference measures will be transformed and recoded based on the scoring keys. 

Categorical variables related to demographic information will be dummy coded, and the first option on the questionnaire will be set as the reference category.

q22.value:
1)	Task duration: Duration per goal is calculated by the total task duration divided by the number of goals listed by a given subject. Outliers are identified and excluded through visual inspection of the histogram. 
2)	Attention check question: Participants will be excluded if they fail 2 or more attention check questions. They will also be excluded if they fail one of the attention check questions in the individual difference session. 
3)	Repetitive responses: The number of repetitive responses in a row across all questions and scales is demonstrated via a histogram and outliers are identified and excluded through visual inspection.
4)	Missing data in the goal rating session: The number of missing data in the goal rating session is demonstrated via a histogram and outliers are identified and excluded through visual inspection.
5)	Missing data in the individual difference session: If a participant misses beyond 1/3 of the question on a given scale, this participant is excluded for that particular scale.

q23.value: Miss data will be stripped before descriptive analysis, such as mean and standard deviation.  Correlations are computed using all complete pairs of observations.

q24.value:
1)	Intercorrelation among goal-related variables: correlations across all 30 variables on goal representation and 5 variables on the current status of goal pursuit. 

2)	Variable reduction: Exploratory factor analysis will be used to reduce the number of variables on goal representation. 
a.	Based on the pilot study, factors are intercorrelated, and therefore, an oblique rotation will be used (“promax” in the “fa” function). 
b.	A “minimum residual” will be used as the factor method. We will use both raw rating scores and centered scores (deviations from the mean scores on a given variable for a given subject). 
c.	The number of extracted factors will be determined based on the Scree plot, eigenvalue. 

3)	Factor scores: Interpreting the meaning of the factors by item loadings and inter-factor correlations. 
a.	Factor scores are transformed from raw scores using the regression based weights

4)	Goal representation across multiple factors: 
a.	Explore the descriptive stats of each factor score
b.	Explore the variation at the within-subject level and between-subject level for each factor using intraclass correlation. 

5)	Pair-wise similarity among goals: 
a.	Quantify pair-wise similarity on the factor scores of goals within a given subject using Euclidean distance
b.	Explore the variation of pair-wise similarity at the within-subject level and between-subject level 
c.	Explore the correlation between pair-wise similarity on factor scores with pair-wise similarity on all five variables related to goal pursing. 

6)	Between subject level correlations:
a.	Explore the correlations among all individual difference measures, mean level factor scores and mean level pair-wise distances. 
b.	Explore the correlations among all individual difference measures, variance in factor scores and variance in pair-wise distances. 

7)	The reliability of self-other ratings on all goal representation variables
a.	For each variable, calculate the intraclass correlation between the two raters and the subject via a multilevel model with person and goal as random intercepts.

q25.value: Prior to this current project, we conducted a pilot study with 54 undergraduate students from the University of Oregon using the same design. The data from the pilot study will not be included in the current project. However, we conducted an exploratory analysis (following the plan listed above) and used the outcomes to finalized the analysis plan.

registration_responses.q1: An Exploratory Analysis on Goal Representation
registration_responses.q3:
The present study is an exploratory project aiming at investigating how people frame and think about their daily goals. Even though there has been a large amount of literature related to the construct of goal, there's little consensus on how we should quantify and measure this multi-dimensional construct. This current project will lay the groundwork for future studies on goal measurement and the dynamic system among multiple goals. 

Specific research questions are 1) Can we reduce represent goals with a limited number of factors? 2) To what extent is each factor visible to other people (self-other rating consistency)? 3) How does the current goal pursuing status affect goal representation on each of the factors 4) How similar are the goals listed by a given participant 5) What are the individual differences that affect goal representation on each factor and the similarity among goals.
registration_responses.q4: This project is exploratory, and therefore we have no specific hypotheses about the relationship between our main variables.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 300, and we will attempt to recruit up to 335, assuming that not all will complete the total task.
registration_responses.q14: This sample size is estimated based on feasibility and time constraint.

Categorical variables related to demographic information will be dummy coded, and the first option on the questionnaire will be set as the reference category.

5)	Missing data in the individual difference session: If a participant misses beyond 1/3 of the question on a given scale, this participant is excluded for that particular scale.

6)	Between subject level correlations:

a.	For each variable, calculate the intraclass correlation between the two raters and the subject via a multilevel model with person and goal as random intercepts.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Attachment, Relationship Satisfaction, and Culture Orientations

sample.value: 333 participants will make up the sample size which is based off the number of subject pool credits received for the study.

analyses.value:
The first question will be addressed using a multiple regression analysis, with relationship satisfaction regressed on parental attachment. Parental attachment is measured with respect to anxiety and avoidance. The equation is below:

(rel_satis) i = β0 + β1(mother_anx) +  β2(father_anx)i + β3(mother_avo) + β4(father_avo)i + ε i

I will be answering the second question using the multiple regression model, with collectivistic culture orientation and individualistic culture orientation regressed on parental attachment respectively. The equation is below:

(culture_col)i = β0 + β1(mother_anx) + β2(father_anx)i + β3(mother_avo) + β4(father_avo)i + ε i

(culture_ind)i = β0 + β1(mother_anx) + β2(father_anx)i + β3(mother_avo) + β4(father_avo)i + ε i

I will be addressing the third question using the multiple regression model below:
 
(rel_satis)i  = β0 + β1(mother_anx) + β2(mother_avo) +β3(father_anx)i + β4(father_avo)i + β5(culture_ind) + β6(culture_col)i + β7(mother_anx × culture_ind) + β8(mother_avo × culture_ind) + β9(father_anx × culture_ind) + β10(father_avo × culture_ind) + β11(mother_anx × culture_col) + β12(mother_avo × culture_col) + β13(father_anx × culture_col) + β14(father_avo × culture_col) + ε i

outliers.value: The participants have to be at least 18 years old and have to be in a romantic relationship to participate in the study.

dependent.value:
Relationship satisfaction: Relationship satisfaction was measured using the Investment Model Scale (IMS; Rusbult et al., 1998), which looked at the relationship satisfaction level in regard to how positive a person feels about the partner and how dedicated and attracted the person is towards the relationship. This questionnaire had 12 questions scored on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). The relationship satisfaction score specifically came from averaging items 4, 5, and 6 from the IMS scale. Item 4 was “I feel satisfied with our relationship”, item 5 was “Our relationship does a good job of fulfilling my needs for intimacy, companionship, etc.”, and item 6 was “My relationship is close to ideal.”  

Parental attachment security: Parental attachment security was measured using The Experiences in Close Relationships-Relationship Structures Questionnaire (ECR-RS; Fraley et al, 2011). This questionnaire had instructions for each relationship domain (Mother, Father, Dating/Marital Partner, Friend). For example, the instructions for the mother relationship domain were to answer questions about the participant’s mother (or mother-like) figure. This was followed by survey questions, such as “I usually discuss my problems and concerns with this person” and “I’m afraid this person will abandon me.” The questionnaire consisted of 9 questions per relational target scored on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Culture orientation (Individualism/Collectivism): Culture orientation was measured using the Measurement of Horizontal and Vertical Individualism and Collectivism (Triandis & Gelfand, 1998), a scale used to measure collectivistic and individualistic cultural orientations.  Example items included “I'd rather depend on myself than others” and “I feel good when I cooperate with others.” The questionnaire had 16 questions scored on a 9-point Likert scale from 1 (never) to 9 (always). There were eight questions each to measure individualism and collectivism.

conditions.value: This is not an experiment. There are 333 participants and no experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value: There are three questions we are examining. First, I will examine the association between parental attachment security and romantic relationship satisfaction. Second, I will investigate the way in which people who hold collectivistic versus individualistic culture orientations differ in their parental attachments. Third, I will examine whether culture orientation moderates the association between parental attachment and relationship satisfaction.

registration_responses.data: Yes, we already collected the data.
registration_responses.name: Attachment, Relationship Satisfaction, and Culture Orientations
registration_responses.sample: 333 participants will make up the sample size which is based off the number of subject pool credits received for the study.
registration_responses.analyses:
The first question will be addressed using a multiple regression analysis, with relationship satisfaction regressed on parental attachment. Parental attachment is measured with respect to anxiety and avoidance. The equation is below:

(rel_satis) i = β0 + β1(mother_anx) +  β2(father_anx)i + β3(mother_avo) + β4(father_avo)i + ε i

I will be answering the second question using the multiple regression model, with collectivistic culture orientation and individualistic culture orientation regressed on parental attachment respectively. The equation is below:

(culture_col)i = β0 + β1(mother_anx) + β2(father_anx)i + β3(mother_avo) + β4(father_avo)i + ε i

(culture_ind)i = β0 + β1(mother_anx) + β2(father_anx)i + β3(mother_avo) + β4(father_avo)i + ε i

I will be addressing the third question using the multiple regression model below:
 
(rel_satis)i  = β0 + β1(mother_anx) + β2(mother_avo) +β3(father_anx)i + β4(father_avo)i + β5(culture_ind) + β6(culture_col)i + β7(mother_anx × culture_ind) + β8(mother_avo × culture_ind) + β9(father_anx × culture_ind) + β10(father_avo × culture_ind) + β11(mother_anx × culture_col) + β12(mother_avo × culture_col) + β13(father_anx × culture_col) + β14(father_avo × culture_col) + ε i
registration_responses.outliers: The participants have to be at least 18 years old and have to be in a romantic relationship to participate in the study.
registration_responses.dependent:
Relationship satisfaction: Relationship satisfaction was measured using the Investment Model Scale (IMS; Rusbult et al., 1998), which looked at the relationship satisfaction level in regard to how positive a person feels about the partner and how dedicated and attracted the person is towards the relationship. This questionnaire had 12 questions scored on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). The relationship satisfaction score specifically came from averaging items 4, 5, and 6 from the IMS scale. Item 4 was “I feel satisfied with our relationship”, item 5 was “Our relationship does a good job of fulfilling my needs for intimacy, companionship, etc.”, and item 6 was “My relationship is close to ideal.”  

Parental attachment security: Parental attachment security was measured using The Experiences in Close Relationships-Relationship Structures Questionnaire (ECR-RS; Fraley et al, 2011). This questionnaire had instructions for each relationship domain (Mother, Father, Dating/Marital Partner, Friend). For example, the instructions for the mother relationship domain were to answer questions about the participant’s mother (or mother-like) figure. This was followed by survey questions, such as “I usually discuss my problems and concerns with this person” and “I’m afraid this person will abandon me.” The questionnaire consisted of 9 questions per relational target scored on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Culture orientation (Individualism/Collectivism): Culture orientation was measured using the Measurement of Horizontal and Vertical Individualism and Collectivism (Triandis & Gelfand, 1998), a scale used to measure collectivistic and individualistic cultural orientations.  Example items included “I'd rather depend on myself than others” and “I feel good when I cooperate with others.” The questionnaire had 16 questions scored on a 9-point Likert scale from 1 (never) to 9 (always). There were eight questions each to measure individualism and collectivism.
registration_responses.conditions: This is not an experiment. There are 333 participants and no experimental conditions.
registration_responses.hypothesis: There are three questions we are examining. First, I will examine the association between parental attachment security and romantic relationship satisfaction. Second, I will investigate the way in which people who hold collectivistic versus individualistic culture orientations differ in their parental attachments. Third, I will examine whether culture orientation moderates the association between parental attachment and relationship satisfaction.

summary.value: Preregistration for SMILE AND SOCIAL ATTRACTIVITY

registration_responses.summary: Preregistration for SMILE AND SOCIAL ATTRACTIVITY

summary.value: The document attached below is a Preregistration for a study related to social attractiveness and smiling.

registration_responses.summary: The document attached below is a Preregistration for a study related to social attractiveness and smiling.

summary.value:
In a previous study, we found that participants rated a Chinese applicant as more worthy or deserving of an Asian scholarship than both the Indian or Filipino applicants. (See pre-registration for the previous study: https://osf.io/nwzht/?view_only=c4cc021073d545ceb68a8a93bd601a7a). Additionally, the Chinese applicant was rated as having a stronger Asian identity and imagined to be more prototypically Asian looking than both the Indian and Filipino applicants. These findings support the hypothesis that East Asians, or Chinese individuals, are perceived as more representative of the overall Asian racial group than South Asians (e.g., Indian individuals), and Southeast Asians (e.g., Filipino individuals). 

In this follow-up study, we are testing the same hypothesis: whether people mentally represent prototypical “Asians” as East Asian (i.e. Chinese individuals) rather than as South Asian (i.e. Indian individuals) or Southeast Asian (i.e. Filipino individuals). However, we aim to more directly examine the proposed mechanism by showing that this effect appears when participants are asked to evaluate applicants in terms of how prototypically Asian the applicants are (or how well they “fit” the definition of what it means to be Asian) but does not emerge for a neutral/general type of evaluation. 

Please see attached pdf file for complete pre-registration of this study.

registration_responses.summary:
In a previous study, we found that participants rated a Chinese applicant as more worthy or deserving of an Asian scholarship than both the Indian or Filipino applicants. (See pre-registration for the previous study: https://osf.io/nwzht/?view_only=c4cc021073d545ceb68a8a93bd601a7a). Additionally, the Chinese applicant was rated as having a stronger Asian identity and imagined to be more prototypically Asian looking than both the Indian and Filipino applicants. These findings support the hypothesis that East Asians, or Chinese individuals, are perceived as more representative of the overall Asian racial group than South Asians (e.g., Indian individuals), and Southeast Asians (e.g., Filipino individuals). 

In this follow-up study, we are testing the same hypothesis: whether people mentally represent prototypical “Asians” as East Asian (i.e. Chinese individuals) rather than as South Asian (i.e. Indian individuals) or Southeast Asian (i.e. Filipino individuals). However, we aim to more directly examine the proposed mechanism by showing that this effect appears when participants are asked to evaluate applicants in terms of how prototypically Asian the applicants are (or how well they “fit” the definition of what it means to be Asian) but does not emerge for a neutral/general type of evaluation. 

Please see attached pdf file for complete pre-registration of this study.

attributes.title: A systematic review of parent training interventions for immigrants

q1.value: A systematic review of parent training interventions for immigrants

q2.value: Nataly Lim, Mark O'Reilly, Adrienne Russell-George, Fabiola Vargas

q3.value: The purpose of the review is to identify parent training interventions for immigrants and identify any cultural adaptations that were made to the interventions.

q4.value: It is hypothesized that the main adaptations will be providing the intervention and materials in the participants' native languages.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This systematic review will be conducted in accordance with PRISMA guidelines.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Preliminary searches have been completed in the following databases: Education Source, Educational Resources Information Center (ERIC), Medline, and PsychINFO. Terms related to parent training and immigrants were used. 

Ancestry searches of articles that meet inclusion criteria and searches of literature reviews and meta-analyses related to interventions for immigrant parents will also be conducted.

question.value:
Types of studies to be included: 
- Participants are immigrants (i.e., were not born in the country that the study is being conducted in)
- The intervention was focused on parenting skills (i.e., parents were being taught skills to be used with their children) 
-  The study used an experimental design that could demonstrate a functional relationship (e.g. multiple baseline, multi-element, reversal, or randomized group design) 

Types of studies to be excluded: 
- Participants are not immigrants
- Data from participants who are immigrants are unable to be disaggregated 
- The intervention did not focus on parenting skills (i.e., parents were being taught skills that did not directly impact their children) 
- The study did not use an experimental design that could demonstrate a functional relationship (i.e., case study, quasi-experimental study, qualitative study)

Study selection will be done in accordance with the PRISMA protocol. Two authors will independently screen least of 20% of titles and abstracts, as well as review at least 20% of full-text articles. The authors will discuss disagreements until a consensus is reached. 

One author will code for the following: (a) design, (b) participant characteristics including language and country of origin, (c) country that the study was conducted in, (d) intervention components, (e) cultural/linguistic adaptations, (f) dependent variables, and (g) outcomes. A second author will check at least 33% of the extracted data. The authors will discuss disagreements until a consensus is reached.

q13.value: This will depend on the number of studies that meet inclusion criteria.

question.value: Primary outcomes include: types of interventions delivered to immigrant parents, outcomes, and adaptations that were made to the interventions.
If data permits, effect sizes will be reported to determine the effectiveness of parenting interventions for immigrants and the moderating effects of different adaptations will be evaluated.
